occurrences.line_text: The faire Medina with her tresses torne,
Betwixt them both the faire Medina sate
Who did them meditate all his life long,
Of God and goodnesse was his meditation.
Which medling with their bloud and earth, he threw
As fresh as flowres in medow greene do grow,
Then came the Bride, the louely Medua came,
To snaky-locke Medusa to repayre,
Where Thames doth the Medway wedd,
Betwixt the Medway and the Thames agreed.
The metall first he mixt with MedÃ¦wart,
Of Iason and Medï¿½ fÂ¦a was ywrit;
The fall of famous children borne of mee,
Behold what ye this day haue done for mee,
For loe he comes, he comes fast after mee.
And is the point of death now turnd fro mee,
Come then, come soone, come sweetest death to mee,
Ah farre be it (said he) Deare dame fro mee,
But mote thy goodlyhed forgiue it mee,
And gratious to that Ladie, as to mee,
Ere long with like againe he boorded mee,
To weet, whence all the wealth late shewd by mee,
All that I need I haue; what needeth mee
Of grace I pray thee, giue to eat and drinke to mee.
But read what wicked hand hath robbed mee
Me brought? ah farre be such reproch fro mee.
Yet flat refusd to haue a do with mee,
And with kind words accoyd, vowing great loue to mee.
That euen to thinke thereof, it inly pitties mee.
Then let mee liue, as louers ought to do,
Which was the roote of all, end your reuenge on mee.
For other meede may hope for none of mee,
With which he bayd and loudly barkt at mee,
Then as it were t'auenge his wrath on mee,
After whose death, his brother seeing mee
And wish the heauens so much had graced mee,
Sayd Calidore ; Now sure it yrketh mee,
The Laurell, meed of mightie Conquerours
And proudly said, Lo there the worthie meed
Disdaind to loose the meed he wonne in fray,
And me thy worthy meed vnto thy Leman take.
But seeled vp with death, shall haue their deadly meed.
Great thankes and goodly meed to that good syre,
Such prayse is shame; but honour vertues meed
Thus said; Old man, great sure shalbe thy meed,
And had of her, faire Helen for his meed,
Said Guyon, Noble Lord, what meed so great,
In meed of these great conquests by them got,
And mournefull meed of ioyes delicious:
Then honour was the meed of victorie,
Which alwayes of his paines he made the chiefest meed.
Vnthankfull wretch (said he) is this the meed,
Most vertuous virgin, glory be thy meed,
Whom Venus to him gaue for meed of worthinesse.
Fame is my meed, and glory vertues pray.
But he her prayd, for mercy, or for meed,
If goodnesse find no grace, nor righteousnesse no meed?
And to him said, Thou wicked man, whose meed
Saying, Ah noble knight, what worthy meed
The meed of them that loue, and do not liue amisse.
Right well deserued as his duefull meed,
Ten thousand thankes did yeeld her for her meed,
That whylome wont to be the victors meed;
Who was right glad to gaine so goodly meed:
From wight vnworthie of so noble meed.
But the proud Nymph would for no worldly meed,
When Iustice was not for most meed outhyred,
What other meed then need me to requight,
But that which yeeldeth vertues meed alway?
Allured be, for prayer nor for meed.
And to his damzell as their rightfull meed,
doe gaine their treasons meed;
And for their paines obtaine of him a goodly meed.
And eke desirous of the offred meed,
Of him, for all his former follies meed,
The which for promise of great meed, vs draue
And sayd; Now sure ye well haue earn'd your meed,
That euer I for meed did vndertake
A garland was the meed of victory.
Yet Calidore so well him wrought with meed,
But fortune now the victors meed did make;
A Rosy girlond was the victors meede:
What may suffise, to be for meede repayd
To bind their doers, to receiue their meede?
Most goodly meede, the fairest Dame aliue:
At least eternall meede shall you abide.
And steale from thee the meede of thy due merit,
Lo faitour there thy meede vnto thee take,
The meede of thy mischalenge and abet:
And much repynd, that both of victors meede,
Shame be his meede (quoth he) that meaneth shame.
She ment him to corrupt with goodly meede;
Both goodly meede of him it purchase may,
And th'actours won the meede meet for their crymes.
Such be the meede of all, that by such mene
For other meede may hope for none of mee,
The meede of his desert for that despight,
The meede whereof shall shortly be thy shame,
With the reuenue of her plenteous meedes:
And winnes an Oliue girlond for her meeds:
Was neuer Prince so meeke and debonaire;
Such were the labours of this Lady meeke,
They turne themselues, at Vnaes meeke request,
His name was meeke Obedience rightfully ared.
He humbly louted in meeke lowlinesse,
Many meeke wordes, to stay and comfort her withall.
Thou a meane Squire, of meeke and lowly place,
And tend our charges with obeisance meeke:
But the faire Virgin was so meeke and mild,
All which, she of him tooke with countenance meeke and mild.
And gentle pangues, with which he maked meeke
Amongst her teares immixing prayers meeke,
And with meeke seruice and much suit did lay
The more that he with meeke intreatie prayd,
To meeke obeysance of loues mightie raine,
Tho turning all his pride to humblesse meeke,
That made him stoupe to ground with meeke humilitie.
Drew to the gate, and there with prayers meeke,
And this misseeming discord meekely lay aside.
And high aduaunced crests downe meekely feld,
Meekely she bowed downe, to weete if life
And meekely stoup vnto the victour strong:
And her to saue from outrage, meekely prayed him.
That to the ground him meekely made to bowe,
And haughtie spirits meekely to adaw,
She at his bidding meekely did arise,
And euery one with meekenesse to her bowes.
And meekest boone, that they imagine mought.
If she will not, dye meekly for her sake;
That could so meekly make proud hearts auale,
And chose in Faery court of meere goodwill,
My hart doth melt with meere compassion,
At length they chaunst to meet vpon the way
Not meet to be of counsell to a king,
Doth meet a cruell craftie Crocodile,
And chaunst vnwares to meet him in the way,
At last she chaunced by good hap to meet
Together with his Squire, arayed meet:
Hight Reuerence. He them with speeches meet
Vpon her siluer anchor, as was meet;
Who them requites with court'sies seeming meet,
But clothes meet to keepe keene could away,
Whence mounting vp, they find purueyance meet
Himselfe thereby reft of his sences meet,
Vpon the way him fortuned to meet,
And entertaine themselues with court'sies meet,
And fell intent ye did at earst me meet;
Me for to meet, that seemed ill bested,
Dan Faunus chaunst to meet her by the way,
And comely courted with meet modestie,
Till that at length with Archimage they meet:
Eftsoones supposed him a person meet,
Her oft to meet: which better to approue,
Her vpper parts of meet habiliments,
Are meet, the which doe men in bale to sterue,
Sheilds, steeds, and armes, & all things for thee meet
Doth not, I weene, so many euils meet.
By faithfull seruice, and meet amenance,
Whom passing by she happened to meet:
To th'instruments diuine respondence meet:
The siluer sounding instruments did meet
And meet respect of honour put to flight:
Pitty our plaint, and yield vs meet reliefe.
Sith other offices for mother meet
Farewell my sweetest sonne, sith we no more shall meet.
Meet for her temper and complexion:
May meet againe, and each take happie chance.
Mote not be entertaynd, as seemed meet,
And timely seruice to her pleasures meet
He fortun'd her to meet, with commune speach
And entertaining her with curt'sies meet,
Till they with mariage meet might finish that accord.
Yet was he meet, vnlesse mine eye did faine,
And eke his garment, to be thereto meet,
In saluage chase, to rest as seem'd her meet.
When all three kinds of loue together meet,
Or zeale of friends combynd with vertues meet.
That all the cares and euill which they meet,
And with meet seruice waited him about;
He chaunst to meet a Dwarfe in hasty course;
And th'actours won the meede meet for their crymes.
Spake, as was meet, for ease of my regret:
To make it seeme more deare and dainty, as is meet.
That nothing meet in marchandise to passe.
At last him chaunst to meete vpon the way
Soone meete they both, both fell and furious,
Do meete, that with the terrour of the shocke
To meete me wandring, who perforce me led
In which him chaunced false Duessa meete,
Where them does meete a francklin faire and free,
A goodly knight, all armd in harnesse meete,
And pleasd them all with meete satietie,
Perhaps my succour, or aduizement meete
If that your liues ye loue, as meete ye should;
They to him hearken, as beseemeth meete,
What seruice may I do vnto thee meete,
Him to receiue with entertainment meete.
Do meete together, each abacke rebowndes
Doe meete together on the watry lea,
That with thy meaning so I may the rather meete.
Of all the heard, meete with so hideous maine,
Not farre away, not meete for any guest
Within a groue appointed him to meete;
Which she receiuing with meete thankefulnesse,
To serue, for want of other meete reward,
Should meete, a trap was letten downe to fall
Them fairely entertaynd with curt'sies meete,
But ran to meete him forth, to know his tidings somme.
She chaunst to meete toward th'euen-tide
He would it meete, and warily withstand.
To meete her at the saluage Ilands syde,
Who streight her leading with meete maiestie
Did issue forth, to meete his foe afore;
I chaunst to meete this knight, who there lyes slaine,
Vnarm'd all was the knight, as then more meete
Then fearing any foeman there to meete:
To clad his corpse with meete habiliments,
With many kindes of medicines meete, to tame
And seeking all things meete for remedy.
And meetes a flood, that doth his passage stay,
Meetes two contrary billowes by the way,
She goes to seeke him, Dolon meetes
Is meetest med'cine, tempred with sweet voice;
As euery one seem'd meetest in that cace.
As meetest may beseeme a noble mayd;
He thereto meeting said, My dearest Dame,
Who meeting earst with Archimago slie,
Where meeting with this Redcrosse knight, she fond
Continuall, both meeting at one time:
And meeting Plim, to Plimmouth thence declines:
Euen in the dore him meeting, she begun;
And meeting him right in the middle race,
Of knights and ladies any meetings were,
Prince Arthur meets with Vna great-
The hard begin, that meets thee in the dore,
With heary glib deform'd, and meiger face,
So as she thus melancholicke did ride,
Full of melancholie and sad misfare,
The pensiue fit of her melancholie;
To driue away the dull melancholy,
To driue away the dull Melancholy;
Sterne melancholy did his courage pas,
His hart in twaine with sad melancholy,
That him full of melancholy did shew;
Yet thought it was not loue, but some melancholy.
And sad melancholy: there he his cabin made.
Then vp she rose fraught with melancholy,
They spoyld old Melibee of all he had,
VVhilest Melibee is slaine:
Calidore hostes with Meliboe
In vaine (said then old Meliboe) doe men
Then forth the good old Meliboe was brought,
Old Meliboe is slaine, and him beside
Old Meliboe and his good wife withall
From Meliboe and from themselues whyleare,
Had reft from Meliboe, and from his make,
But Meliboee (so hight that good old man)
Of good king Meliogras which did rayne
And her owne handmayd, that Melissa hight,
Lifht goote Cymothoe, and sweete Melite,
With holy father sits not with such things to mell.
Not fit mongst men, that doe with reason mell,
That euery matter worse was for her melling,
Where many Mermayds haunt, making false melodies.
Etfsoones they heard a most melodious sound,
There many Minstrales maken melody,
And all the while, most heauenly melody
And their sweet skill in wonted melody;
And let him heare some part of their rare melody.
Their daintie layes and dulcet melody,
That the rare sweetnesse of the melody
To Colins melody:
That nigh his manly hart did melt away,
Her hart gan melt in great compassion,
And chearefull bloud in faintnesse chill did melt,
His heart did seeme to melt in pleasures manifold.
Neither to melt in pleasures whot desire,
Ne let thy stout hart melt in pitty vayne:
To melt the golden metall, ready to be tride.
Would make to melt, or pitteously appall;
My hart doth melt with meere compassion,
Of huge affection, did in pleasure melt,
And eft gan into tender teares to melt.
For passing ioy, which did all into pitty melt.
Her snowy substance melted as with heat,
Melting in teares, then gan she thus lament;
The sugred licour through his melting lips:
And all, that might his melting hart entise
That with his melting sweetnesse rauished,
Besides all hope with melting eyes did vew,
In sted thereof with drops of melting loue,
That can with melting pleasaunce mollifye
Hong still vpon his melting mouth attent;
With many a ioyfull kisse, and many a melting teare.
And with that suddein horror could no member moue.
And eger greedinesse through euery member thrild.
She softly felt, if any member mooued,
That euery member of his bodie quooke.
And made ech member quake, and manly hart to quayle.
Was quite dismembred, and his members chast
That so deepe wound through these deare members driue.
Yet in his frosen members did remaine,
Were painted faire with memorable gestes,
Which of his name and memorable gest
And to enroll thy memorable name,
But he of rope or armes has now no memoree.
The third things past could keepe in memoree,
That yet remaines his wide memoriall:
He might for memorie of that dayes ruth,
Yet liues his memorie, though carcas sleepe in rest.
O ioyous memorie of happy time,
Beene suncke, of whom no memorie did stay:
They do impart, ne maken memorie
Daughter of Phoebus and of Memorie,
Which shall reuiue the sleeping memorie
For memorie of which on high there hong
Are washt away quite from their memorie.
And endlesse memorie, that mote excell,
The noursling of Dame Memorie his deare,
Espide, he gan reuiue the memory
Is, as it were for endlesse memory
Both good and ill: O mornefull memory:
Rather then matter of iust memory,
Fresh memory in me of that great Queene,
And inly tremble at the memory
Left of his life most famous memory,
Where thee yet shall he leaue for memory
Of which, that field for endlesse memory,
And quite from of th'earth their memory be rast?
Ne of thy late life memory is left,
As to his memory they had recourse:
Nor memory thereof to any nation.
Next Memprise, as vnworthy of that place,
The fearefull Dwarfe:) this is no place for liuing men.
Whither the soules do fly of men, that liue amis.
Both which fraile men do oftentimes mistake,
He did disrobe, when all men carelesse slept,
And proud Lucifera men did her call,
Of that fowle euill, which all men reproue,
Dead sculs & bones of men, whose life had gone astray.
And sight of men, since his late luckelesse fray.
And damned sprights sent forth to make ill men aghast.
Amongst these mighty men were wemen mixt,
Of murdred men which therein strowed lay,
Emongst wild beasts and woods, from lawes of men exilde.
Then for to make her dreaded more of men,
Men into stones therewith he could transmew,
Vnlike to men, who euer as they trace,
That blisse may not abide in state of mortall men.
Dame Cï¿½lia men did her call, as thought
O foolish men, why haste ye to your owne decay?
Sometimes great hostes of men she could dismay,
That drew on men Gods hatred, and his wrath,
Ne ought the powre of mighty men did dread
Such men do Chaungelings call, so chaungd by Faeries theft.
Of tall young men, all hable armes to sownd,
Such is the state of men: thus enter wee
O miserable men, that to him subiect arre.
That men beholding so great excellence,
He gan to hope, of men to be receiu'd
Vnto his brother, whom Cymochles men did call.
Are meet, the which doe men in bale to sterue,
For which men swinck and sweat incessantly,
With which weake men thou witchest, to attend:
Are mortall men so fond and vndiscreet,
Frayle men are oft captiu'd to couetise:
To which all men do ayme, rich to be made:
Far passing th'hight of men terrestriall;
More fit amongst blacke fiendes, then men to haue his place.
Through the dim shade, that all men might it see:
For which ye men do striue: few get, but many mis.
Throwes forth to men, sweet and well sauoured,
For now three dayes of men were full outwrought,
Of men, then beasts. But ï¿½ th'exceeding grace
The worth of all men by their end esteeme,
The wisest men, I weene, that liued in their ages.
Three ages, such as mortall men contriue,
Of hideous Giants, and halfe beastly men,
That sonnes of men amazd their sternnesse to behold.
As farre exceeded men in their immeasurd mights.
And courage fierce, that all men did affray,
Which of her name now Seuerne men do call:
And first taught men a woman to obay:
The reach of men, through flight into fond mischief fell.
Then made he sacred lawes, which some men say
And both of them men of renowmed might;
And all that now America men call:
As th'Isle of Delos whylome men report
Such as by nature men abhorre and hate,
Said he, These seeming beasts are men indeed,
And streight of beasts they comely men became;
Yet being men they did vnmanly looke,
And we your liege men faith vnto you plight.
Here haue I cause, in men iust blame to find,
Till enuious Men fearing their rules decay,
That now we foolish men that prayse gin eke t'enuy.
Yet she might all men vew out of her bowre?
And reft from men the worlds desired vew,
The time, that mortall men their weary cares
And thence pourd into men, which men call Loue;
And thence pourd into men, which men call Loue;
Huge hostes of men he could alone dismay,
And hostes of men of meanest things could frame,
And sooth, men say that he was not the sonne
Nor so fowle outrage doen by liuing men:
Their beames shall oft breake forth, that men them faire may see.
Performd, in paragone of proudest men:
Faire Angela (quoth she) men do her call,
And boastfull men so oft abasht to heare?
Desired rest, and men of happinesse depriue.
That mortall men her glory should admire
Infinite shapes of creatures men do fynd,
By which both in and out men moten pas;
Pleasure, that doth both gods and men aggrate,
And drunke with bloud of men, slaine by his might,
These twinnes, men say, (a thing far passing thought)
To seeke young men, to quench her flaming thurst,
By errant Sprights, but from all men conceald:
The fairest wight on ground, and most of men esteemed.
Which now in Faerie court all men do tell,
Both light of heauen, and strength of men relate:
Ne cares, what men say of him ill or well;
What to Aeneas fell; sith that men sayne
That all men feare to tempt his billowes strong,
False loue, why do men say, thou canst not see,
And all men busie to suppresse the flame,
But minds of mortall men are muchell mard,
In th'harts of men, them gouerne wisely well,
The wrongfull outrage of vnrighteous men,
Calling men to their daily exercize,
Amongst fraile men, that many a publike state
Which punish wicked men, that walke amisse:
Both for his worth, that all men did adore,
As men awaked rashly out of dreme,
All mightie men and dreadfull derring dooers,
Most wretched men, whose dayes depend on thrids so vaine.
O   Why doe wretched men so much desire,
That made them dreaded much of all men farre and nie.
As all men do, that lose the liuing spright:
Few men, but such as sober are and sage,
Such famous men, such worthies of the earth,
For that had might to change the hearts of men
And they like men astonisht still did stand.
When all men saw this sudden change of things,
That men on him the more might gaze alone.
He open shewd, that all men it mote marke.
That all men threw out vowes and wishes vaine.
Much wondred all men, what, or whence he came,
Whom all men term'd Knight of the Hebene speare,
That all men wondred at the vncouth sight,
Of men and beasts; and fed on fleshly gore,
Now twenty daies, by which the sonnes of men
The shame of men, and plague of womankind,
But in that wildernesse, of men forlore,
And wickedly backbite: Her name men Sclaunder call.
To sinfull men with darknes ouerdight,
Ne hostes of men with banners brode dispred,
That all men much admyrde her change, and spake her praise.
On either side of her, two young men stood,
The ioy of Gods and men, that vnder skie
Great God of men and women, queene of th'ayre,
Mongst men of worth, I to her stepped neare,
Can from all men so rich a kingdome hold;
And shame on you, ï¿½ men, which boast your strong
The Ouze, whom men doe Isis rightly name;
Of which the auncient Lincolne men doe call;
Bewrayd it selfe, to let men plainely wot,
Whom of their sire Nereides men call,
And men themselues, the which at first were framed
And all men sought their owne, and none no more;
For that which all men then did vertue call,
Peace vniuersall rayn'd mongst men and beasts,
Which lawlesse men had formerly fordonne.
Astrï¿½a here mongst earthly men did dwell,
And men admyr'd his ouerruling might;
Mongst wicked men, in whom no truth she found,
That makes all men for feare that passage for to shonne.
To be a mirrour to all mighty men,
Tyrants that make men subiect to their law,
And all the wealth of rich men to the poore will draw.
When all men had with full satietie
So they disparted were, and all men went to rest.
That all men stood amaz'd, & at his might did wonder.
That all men wonder at her colours pride;
And in the sight of all men cleane disgraced,
Right true: but faulty men vse oftentimes
As that, albe all loue of men she scorne,
She yet forgets, that she of men was kynded:
The art of mightie words, that men can charme;
Some men, I wote, will deeme in Artegall
Of armed men, comming with close intent
That Gods and men doe equally adore,
For th'heuens the[m]selues, whence mortal men implore
Hauing the mindes of men with fury fraught,
Of men disguiz'd in womanishe attire,
To captiue men, and make them all the world reiect.
Her name Mercilla most men vse to call;
With flesh of men, whom through fell tyranny
That all men which that spectacle did see,
Of knights and armed men, which did maintaine
